description: As you wind through a maple-basswood forest, look for trumpeter swans and otter at Mary, Allen and Kasey lakes. Climb the 100-foot tall fire tower (closed in winter) for a panoramic view of the Lake Itasca watershed. It’s a great place to view fall colors.
This boardwalk trail provides safe walking/biking between the Bear Paw campground and the main bike trail near the University of Minnesota Biological Station entrance.
As you loop through spruce and fir, look for signs of beaver activity near the creek. This is a “minimum maintenance” trail, sometimes blocked by fallen trees and open only during the summer.

From a parking lot near Nicollet Creek, access Minnesota’s former record red pine. Though it’s still impressive, a storm in 2007 sheared off its top. Here, too, is the Bison Kill Site, where archaeologists recovered the 8,000-year-old bones of extinct bison and the tools long-ago hunters used to hunt and process them.

A paved bicycle trail along the east side of Lake Itasca connects Douglas Lodge to the Mississippi Headwaters. For a full bike tour of the park, continue another 10 miles on  Wilderness Drive. (Share the road with vehicles.) The entire loop is 16 miles.

The Blowdown Trail, named for the 1995 storm that damaged 3,000+ acres of Itasca’s forest, showcases the effects of nature’s forces. Learn about different ways foresters handle windstorm-damaged trees. This rustic loop offers excellent birdwatching.
This rustic path, in the heart of the Wilderness Sanctuary, winds past towering red and white pines on its way to secluded Bohall Lake. Keep a lookout for black-backed woodpeckers.

Hike along the east shore of Lake Itasca from Douglas Lodge to the boat landing at Bear Paw Campground. The rustic trail takes you past some of the largest, oldest pines in the park. Near Douglas Lodge, look for the esker—a formation created when a stream under a glacier left behind gravel and sediment. Watch for loons, eagles and osprey.

Follow the short, self-guided trail into this Civilian Conservation Corps tree plantation—21,000 red pines and 5,500 white spruce seeded in the late 1930s. The trail begins in the pine plantation, then passes through a mix of spruce and hardwoods.

Deer Park Trail is part of the Hiking Club Route. Steep in parts, this long, scenic path passes several lakes. It winds through birch and aspen that blaze yellow and gold in autumn. Watch for loons at McKay Lake.

Originally a fire emergency road, this aspen-lined trail passes some old-growth pines and sugar maple stands. For a shorter loop, take the McKay Lake Crossover at the midpoint of the DeSoto Trail and return on the Deer Park Trail.

This portage trail leads paddlers to Hernando DeSoto Lake. Walk through pine stands, past wetlands and through hardwood forest on the way to the lake. Find the trailhead near the parking access along Highway 113.

Borrow or buy a guide (available at park gift shops) and follow the numbered posts along this self-guided nature trail down the hill from Douglas Lodge. One-quarter mile of accessible boardwalk crosses a bog to the Old Timer’s Cabin. The rest of the trail loops through pine, birch, aspen and mixed hardwood forest along the ridge overlooking Lyendecker Lake. This is an excellent trail for wildflower photography.

This hilly route winds through pine stands and offers spectacular views of remote lakes. South of the Ozawindib Trail junction is the Iron Corners historical marker indicating the junction of three Minnesota counties.

This trail, once part of the early 1900s Jefferson Highway system, runs north through young aspen and old white and red pines to the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center. You can park at an unmarked pullout on the north side of the East Entrance Road. Three concrete posts mark the trail’s start. At its end, look for the Civilian Conservation Corps land survey section corner marker.

This accessible trail starts at the Mary Gibbs Headwaters Center and leads to the outlet of Lake Itasca—the park’s most popular attraction. At the Headwaters viewing area, you can walk across the rocks, cross the log footbridge or wade through the shallow water at the start of the Mississippi River.
The Woodland Period Indians who lived at Itasca 3,000 to 350 years ago buried their dead in these mounds at the north end of today’s picnic grounds. Please respect this site and remain on the trail.

This rustic, self-guided trail begins at the Wilderness Sanctuary parking area off Wilderness Drive and runs through a variety of forest types—from young aspen and birch to 100–300-year-old white and red pines. The path crosses hills and several small wetlands.
This path leads to one of Minnesota’s largest white pines. Towering over its neighbors, the 300-year-old tree is a favorite photo opportunity for Itasca visitors.
LaSalle Trail loops through a mixed forest of hardwoods and conifers, including old-growth red and white pines, younger pines, white spruce and balsam fir.

This accessible trail starts behind the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center and winds through a dense grove of large red pines. Interpretive signs explain the forces that have shaped Itasca’s forest and suggest other park trails. Bird feeders near the trail are busy, especially in the winter.

Walk through old-growth forest along the northeast shore of Mary Lake to the Deer Exclosure. In the 1930s, the Civilian Conservation Corps built a fence (now removed) to keep deer out of these pines. Compare pine growth in and out of the once-fenced area.
This path connects the De Soto and Deer Park trails, creating a variety of loop options for hikers and cross-country skiers.
This trail winds through stands of red pine and mixed forest. Look for black-backed woodpeckers.
This path connects the Deer Park, Red Pine and Ozawindib trails, creating a variety of loop options for hikers and cross-country skiers. It's part of the Hiking Club Route.

This former truck trail passes through diverse forest—big pines, spruce, balsam fir, birch and aspen—on its way from Wilderness Drive to Hernando DeSoto Lake. Nicollet Cabin, built to house Minnesota Forest Rangers in the early 1900s, stands one mile from the north end of the trail. Look for signs of wolves, fox and woodpeckers.

This route, built and maintained by volunteers, is part of 4,600 miles of National Scenic Trail system stretching from New York to North Dakota. As it passes through Itasca State Park, it connects several park trails.

This short path between the Red Pine and Ozawindib trails leads to pine-covered Okerson Heights—one of Itasca’s highest points. The trail is minimally maintained, sometimes blocked by fallen trees and open only during the summer.

This hilly path on the west side of Mary Lake passes through mixed forests of pine, birch, maple and aspen. Look for wildflowers, blazing fall colors, and the Lind Saddle Trail marker near the Myrtle Lake Crossover. Ozawindib Trail is part of the Hiking Club Route.

The Red Pine Trail passes through large stands of red pine and winds past a few small lakes. Most of Red Pine is a summer trail, but the first spur is open in winter to skiers accessing the Ozawindib Trail from South Entrance Road.

This grassy trail leads through hardwood forests to the old Hemmerich Sawmill at Pioneer Farmers Village. Watch for a variety of ferns. To see the sawmill in action, check the program calendar for naturalist-led tours and demonstrations (summer only).
This route offers excellent birdwatching and a stunning view of Schoolcraft Island and Lake Itasca. Watch for warblers, kinglets, loons, eagles and osprey.

Once a forestry road, the Two Spot Trail leads west from Wilderness Drive to the Twin Lakes on the park’s western edge. Named for a 1920s-era steam engine, the trail passes through aspen, birch, and sugar and red maples. Look for wildflowers and wildlife near the trail’s end.

Take in the panoramic view from atop this 100-foot-tall tower, constructed by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s. At the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center, pick up a pamphlet about fire towers and their use in forestry.
Located in the picnic area, this amphitheater has a view of the lake and is a popular site for naturalist programs.

In 1937, workers discovered bison bones and human artifacts as they were rebuilding part of Wilderness Drive. Hunters ambushed, killed and dressed huge bison at this site near Nicollet Creek some 8,000 years ago.

The accessible boardwalk section of the Dr. Roberts Trail passes through a black spruce and tamarack bog. This habitat is home to a variety of plants and birds, including the showy lady’s slipper and the white-throated sparrow.

In the 1930s, hungry deer over-browsed on white pine seedlings. To protect the trees, Civilian Conservation Corps workers built a fence. After a hunting season was established in 1945, deer became less of a problem. Recently, the fence was removed, but it’s easy to see where the boundary used to be.
Dedicated in 1905 and built in the Rustic Style popular in that era, Douglas Lodge is the oldest building in the park.
Completed by the Veterans Conservation Corps in 1941, this log-and-stone building replaced the original Forest Inn. Inside, you’ll find park information and a gift shop.

The old Park Headquarters, built in 1922, stands across from the Itasca Boat Landing. Restored in 1992, the building now offers year-round accommodations through Hostelling International. Tours of the building are generally available evenings and weekends.

Nestled under the pines, this Civilian Conservation Corps-constructed log cabin once served as the contact station for visitors entering the park. You can now rent the historic cabin for an overnight stay.

This site is a Woodland Period Indian cemetery. The people who lived at Itasca 3,000 to 350 years ago buried their dead in mounds. Laws protect the mounds and prohibit their disturbance. Please respect this site and remain on the trail.

The Lake Itasca Boat Landing provides public access to Lake Itasca. Refer to a park map for locations of other public boat landings. For rentals and the sale of boating and fishing needs, see the Itasca Sports Rental brochure.

Built in 1925, the Itasca Museum building was once known as the Oza Windib campground shelter. After the campground moved to Bear Paw in the 1930s, the log building served as a beach changing house and community gathering place before becoming the natural history museum.

The sawmill, originally operated by Roy Hemmerich, was moved to its present site in 1952. Purchased by the state in 1971, the sawmill still fires up for demonstrations and special projects led by the Lake Itasca Region Pioneer Farmers.

Here, you can pick up park brochures, learn about the park’s natural and cultural history, and buy souvenirs and permits. The visitor center is open year-round and serves as a warming shelter in winter.

During the Ice Age, water flowing under glaciers carved out the three long, narrow arms of Lake Itasca. In 1932, Henry Rowe Schoolcraft, led by Ojibwe guide Ozawindib, identified the lake as the source of the Mississippi River, which flows 2,552 miles to the Gulf of Mexico.
At Mary GIbbs Headwaters Center, a roof shelters a large-scale 3D map of the Mississippi River and interpretive displays. It also features restrooms, a gift shop and a café.
Follow this short trail to view one of Minnesota’s largest white pines. Measuring 55” in diameter, this massive tree is the largest white pine in the park.
Step across the rocks, walk across the log footbridge or wade in the water. Here, the 18-foot-wide Mississippi River begins its winding journey 2,552 miles to the Gulf of Mexico.

Nicollet Cabin was built in 1917 to house foresters whose job included marking trees that shouldn’t be logged. Game wardens, fire crews, hunters and vacationers also used the cabin until 1965. Restored in 1995, the historic cabin is a reminder of foresters’ remote lives in the early 1900s.

You'll find the Old Timer's Cabin at the end of the accessible boardwalk section of the Dr. Roberts Trail. The Civilian Conservation Corps constructed it in 1934 of pine logs so large that the building is only four logs high.

Surrounded by mixed-pine forest, the overlook at Peace Pipe Vista offers a stunning view of Lake Itasca. It’s a favorite place for park visitors to watch the sunset, take pictures and listen for loons.
Fourteen of Itasca’s earliest settlers, including William McMullen and Theodore and Johanna Wegmann, are buried in this cemetery near the Boat Landing.
This serene stand of old-growth red pine is named for a preachers’ convention held at the site in the early 1900s.

This hill above the Douglas Lodge cabins is an "esker"—a formation created when a stream under a glacier left behind gravel and sediment. In 1832, Henry Rowe Schoolcraft's expedition portaged six miles from Lake Alice and over the hill to get their first view of Lake Itasca. Discover the commemorative plaque near Cabin 7.

The University of Minnesota Biological Station offers an extensive research program in forestry and ecology. The station's findings have helped maintain and sustain Itasca’s valuable natural resources since 1909.

Theodore Wegmann was the park’s first game warden. He and his wife, Johanna, settled in the Itasca area in 1893. Soon after, they opened the first store and post office. The ruins remain at this site, which is now part of the picnic area.

Eleven-mile Wilderness Drive runs through the less-developed middle and west side of the park from the Mississippi Headwaters to Douglas Lodge. The road is narrow, curvy in places, and one-way from the Ozawindib Group Camp road to Mary Lake. Please drive slowly and watch for parked cars and cyclists as you enjoy the spectacular scenery.

In 1939, 2,000 acres of Itasca’s virgin forest were set aside as a wilderness sanctuary. In 1965, the National Park Service named the sanctuary a Registered National Landmark, and the State of Minnesota recognized this patch of forest as a State Scientific and Natural Area in 1982. Wilderness Drive is the western and southern boundary of the Sanctuary. Several stopping points and trails allow you to experience Itasca's original pine forest.

Eleven backpack campsites are available year-round. To reach them, campers must hike up to five miles from the southern half of the park. Sites have fire rings and pit toilets, but bring your own wood and water. Check in at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center.

Open fishing-opener weekend through mid-October, Bear Paw Campground offers 68 drive-in campsites (34 with electricity) and 11 cart-in sites (300 yards or fewer). Two campsites are wheelchair-accessible. A modern toilet facility with accessible showers and a RV sanitation station are also available.
Elk Lake is a primitive camp for up to 50 campers in tents, trailers, campers or RVs. It has hand-pumped water, vault toilets, fire rings, picnic tables and a small screened shelter.

Lake Ozawindib Group Center provides a commercial kitchen, a dining hall, a counselor cabin, restrooms with accessible showers and a tenting area. The site accommodates up to 75 campers. For reservations contact Itasca State Park at 218-699-7251.

On the site of a 1930s Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) camp, Pine Ridge Campground offers 155 campsites (65 with electricity). Two campsites are wheelchair-accessible. Four modern, accessible toilet facilities with hot showers are open mid-May through early October. Winter camping is rustic, with vault toilets. Water is available at the Visitor Center.

Firewood is available for purchase at the campground office or through self-service stands in the campgrounds, near the Visitor Center or by the Douglas Lodge cabins.To prevent the spread of invasive species, like the emerald ash borer, only use firewood purchased at Itasca or from vendors selling firewood approved for the park.
The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) built six one-room log cabins at Bear Paw Campground in the 1930s.
Once the Bear Paw Campground store and manager’s residence, this 1935 log building is now a 3-bedroom guesthouse for up to 10 people. It’s open from late May through early October.
This CCC-built log cabin contains four studio-style units. The four-plex is open from late May through early October.

Twelve one-, two-, and three-bedroom cabins stand on the southeast shore of Lake Itasca near Douglas Lodge. See the Itasca website for other information about accessibility and amenities, as these vary by cabin. The cabins are available from late May through early October.

Douglas Lodge has been accommodating guests from Memorial Day through early October for more than 100 years. The first floor offers a comfortable lobby with a stone fireplace and a public dining room. Restored historic single and double rooms are available upstairs.
Once the information and permit booth, this CCC-built log cabin just up the hill from Douglas Lodge is now a rental unit available from late May through early October.

Built in the early 1920s, the Headwaters Hostel building was once the park headquarters. Now operated by Hosteling International, the 31-bed facility offers year-round lodging for park visitors. Call in advance, as the hostel sometimes closes weekdays or during the slowest times of the year. Get contact information at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center.

The Clubhouse, built in 1911, is ideal for large groups. Ten sleeping rooms, six bathrooms, a common area with a balcony and a fireplace, and a large screened porch with a lake view make the Clubhouse a wonderful setting for family reunions and retreats. The building offers heat and air conditioning but no indoor cooking facilities, and is available from late May through early October.

Set in two modern six-plexes, each of six two-room suites (sleep 2–4) offers a bedroom with two queen beds, a sitting area, a kitchenette and a screened porch. These also offer AC/heat, cable television, and wi-fi. Larger groups can connect adjacent units via interior and screen porch doors. The four-season suites are available year-round.

This two-bedroom (sleeps 8) seasonal cabin perches on the shore of remote Lake Ozawindib. It offers heat, a full kitchen (fresh water is available from an outside pump), a living room with a fireplace and a vault toilet. Enjoy the wilderness setting from the screened porch or the dock—a rowboat and a canoe are supplied. Bring your own towels.

Bring your bike or rent one at Itasca Sports
Rental. Itasca offers a 6-mile paved bike trail and an additional 10 miles of biking along Wilderness Drive. The Mississippi River Trail (MRT) bike route also begins within Itasca State Park.

Itasca, Ozawindib, Elk and Mary Lakes are accessible via boat landings. Hernando DeSoto Lake is accessible by portage. Rent canoes, pontoons, paddle boats and more at Itasca Sports Rental at the Lake Itasca boat landing.

Itasca’s 100+ lakes and streams are home to walleye, muskie, northern pike and largemouth bass, and panfish such as crappie, sunfish and perch. Borrow a free fishing kit at Douglas Lodge. For fishing rentals and supplies, refer to the Itasca Sports Rental brochure.
You’ll find fish cleaning shelters at the Lake Itasca Boat Landing, Bear Paw Campground and Douglas Lodge.
A fishing pier with a cleaning shelter and canoe/kayak access is located by Douglas Lodge on Lake Itasca.
The Lake Ozawindib fishing pier and boat access are located in the northwest corner of the park off Wilderness Drive.

Open from early May to mid-October, Itasca Sports rents bicycles, boats, pontoons, canoes, kayaks and other outdoor recreation
equipment. You can also buy snacks, supplies and camping items, and get information about fishing opportunities and lake conditions.
Find playgrounds near the picnic area/swimming beach, near Douglas Lodge, and at Pine Ridge and Bear Paw Campgrounds.

Gather under the towering pines and share a meal. You'll find picnic tables along Lake Itasca from the swimming beach to the Indian Mounds parking lot. Picnic tables and fire rings are available on a first come, first served basis.

The Visitor Center serves as a warming shelter and is open 24/7 during the peak winter season. Inside, explore park exhibits, find a souvenir, get snacks from the vending machines, buy park permits and Great Minnesota Ski Passes or rent snowshoes. Ski trails start at the main kiosks next to the parking lots.
Bundle up and stay safe while ice fishing for walleye, muskie, northern pike and panfish on one of Itasca's lakes.
Cross-country ski trails are groomed for classic and skate skiing. Check at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center for trail maps and grooming updates.

Enjoy 31 miles of trails through the big pines around the perimeter of the park and to the Mississippi Headwaters. Snowmobiles may only be used on designated trails. Snowmobile trailer parking is available at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center's north lot.

Rent snowshoes at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center. Most of the park is open for winter hiking and snowshoeing, and the Brower, Dr. Roberts, LaSalle, Schoolcraft and Maadaadizi trails are designated snowshoe trails. Please stay off roads and ski or snowmobile trails.
Discover the history behind the log and stone buildings in the Douglas Lodge area. Pick up your free, self-guided walking tour brochure at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center.

Take a naturalist-led tour of scenic Lake Itasca aboard the independently owned and operated Chester Charles II excursion boat. Buy tickets at the Wheelhouse Office on the pier 15 minutes before boarding. Check park bulletin boards for the schedule.

State Park naturalists lead activities year-round. A schedule of daily activities—hikes, children’s programs, evening talks, twilight strolls, and campfire programs—is available at park information points.
Enjoy the day at Lake Itasca's sandy swimming beach, with its volleyball court and playground. The beach also offers a changing house with showers and a picnic area.

Open from early May to mid-October, Itasca Sports rents bicycles, boats, pontoons, canoes, kayaks and other outdoor recreation equipment. You can also buy snacks, supplies and camping items, and get information about fishing opportunities and lake conditions.
At the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center, you can borrow a birding kit filled with binoculars, a guide book and a bird checklist. You can also rent snowshoes here in the winter.
Fishing kits (rod, reel and stocked tackle box) and kids’ discovery kits (activities vary) are available at Douglas Lodge.
Borrow a birding kit (binoculars, guide book and bird checklist) or a kids’ discovery kit (activities vary) at the Campground Registration Office.
The full-service restaurant in historic Douglas Lodge—open Memorial Day through early October—serves breakfast, lunch and dinner with a Minnesota theme.

Cool off with ice cream, enjoy sandwiches, soup or salad, or get pizza to go at the cafeteria-style Headwaters Café. It’s open Memorial Day weekend through early October at the Mary Gibbs Mississippi Headwaters Center.
Groceries and gas are available near the north and east entrances to the park.
The Forest Inn gift shop offers northwoods-themed souvenirs, clothing, field guides, books and Douglas Lodge china. Open Memorial Day weekend to early October.
The gift shop at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center is open year-round. Along with souvenirs, you can buy park permits and The Great Minnesota Ski Pass, borrow birding kits or rent snowshoes.
The Mary Gibbs Mississippi Headwaters Center gift shop offers Mississippi River-themed items from late May into October.
Stop here to make a same-day camping reservation, get firewood or ice, or ask questions about camping.

The Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center is your year-round one-stop shop for park information. You can also reserve/check in for lodging or campsites, buy park permits and The Great Minnesota Ski Pass, borrow birding kits or consult area services brochures and maps.

Exhibits at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center cover Mississippi River exploration, the pine forest ecosystem, Ojibwe culture, the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) and early tourism in the park. The Visitor Center is open daily except Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day.
Open early May through mid-October, the Lakeside Museum offers exhibits about the natural and cultural history of Itasca State Park.
Outdoor exhibits provide year-round information about the Mississippi River. A café, modern restrooms and gift shop are open seasonally.

Naturalists lead activities weekends and weekdays during the summer and fall, and periodically during the winter and spring. A schedule of daily activities—hikes, children’s programs, evening talks, twilight strolls, and campfire programs—is available at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center and the Campground Registration Office and posted on park information boards.

Modern restrooms are open year-round at the Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center. Other modern restrooms are open seasonally. Primitive toilets are available throughout the park year-round. See park maps for specific locations.
Rental bikes are available at Itasca Sports Rental near the Lake Itasca boat landing from May through mid-October.
The bike trail is groomed for classic skiing in winter.
Naturalists are available to lead group and school programs at the parks. Charter bus tour options are also available, but a fee applies.

The search for the Mississippi's source brought many explorers to northern Minnesota. In 1832, Ojibwe guide Ozawindib led Henry Rowe Schoolcraft to Lake Itasca and the headwaters of the Mississippi River.
From Itasca State Park, the Mississippi River flows north to Lake Bemidji. Then it winds south and east to Cass Lake and on to the Gulf of Mexico.
More than 300 years ago, forest fires allowed these awe-inspiring trees to sprout. Please stay on the footpath so future visitors can enjoy the grove, too.
Though the Center closes for the winter, the Headwaters Trail and exhibits are open year-round.

The view from the top is worth the climb. As you ascend the caged stairway, interpretive signs describe different levels of the tree canopy. The tower is closed in winter and during inclement weather.

Douglas Lodge still offers its original rustic charm. Even the original furniture and decor have been preserved or restored. Spend the night in a historic room or have a meal in the full-service restaurant. The Lodge is open late May through early October.
Rooms suitable for conferences, meetings, weddings and family reunions are also available at Douglas Lodge. For more information, contact Itasca State Park at 218-699-7251.
Forest Inn can be reserved for weddings, meetings and other private gatherings. For more information, contact Itasca State Park at 218-699-7251.
The Jacob V. Brower Visitor Center classroom offers space for meetings as well as naturalist programs.

Further along Wilderness Drive, the Big Pine Trail leads to a red pine more than 300 years old. Once Minnesota's tallest red pine (and national co-champion), the tree's top was sheared off in a 2007 windstorm.
A replica of the original Wegmann store was built next to the ruins in the 1970s.
In winter, Wilderness Drive closes to car traffic and parts of the roadway become ski and snowmobile trails.
Ice is available at the Campground Registration Office, Douglas Lodge or Itasca Sports Rental.
Open from late May through early October, the ice vending machine at the Campground Registration Office also offers purified water.

Each features a kitchenette with a cooktop and an under-counter refrigerator, a washroom (no tub or shower, but campground showers are nearby), a full bed and futon (sleeps 4), a fireplace and a fire ring. These cabins are available from late May through early October.
The guesthouse offers a full kitchen, accessible bathrooms, a fireplace and a screened-in front porch with a view of Lake Itasca.
Each until sleeps two and offers a fireplace, an outdoor fire ring and a screened porch with a view of Lake Itasca.

Three double rooms (sleep 4) offer private washrooms and showers. Guests in the four single rooms (sleep 2), each with a full bed and period furnishings, share the three bathrooms along the hallway. Douglas Lodge is heated and air-conditioned, but it lacks an elevator.
Rooms suitable for conferences, meetings, weddings and family reunions are also available at Douglas Lodge.
The Historic East Cabin offers two bedrooms (sleeps 6), a bathroom with a tub/shower, a living room with a fireplace, and a full kitchen, as well as a screened gazebo and a fire ring.

The Mississippi River Water Trail begins here in Itasca State Park. Between the Headwaters and the Iowa border, the 667-mile stretch of trail flows through valleys, bluffs, prairies and woodlands. Maps are available on the DNR website.

Built to recall the design of a 1930s shelter constructed by the Civilian Conservation Corps, the picnic shelter offers historic charm and modern conveniences such as electricity. Contact the park office to reserve it.
State Park naturalists are available to lead group and school programs at the park. Charter bus tour options are also available, but a fee applies.
